item.description:
PLEASE -- TAKE A FEW MINUTES AND REVIEW ALL THE TRIP DETAILS BELOW. By signing up you have agreed to our GROUP GUIDELINES.


EVENT ORGANIZER:
Julie Moran Please contact me here with your thoughts and ideas about this trip: jmmoran @ nycap.rr.com, Mobile 518-281-5882. PLEASE -- no calls except for day-of scheduling issues. You can text me as well.


The glory of Fall in full blaze: The Bucklin Trail to Killington Peak.



ESSENTIAL TRIP DETAILS:

Difficulty: About 9.6 miles, about 3,200 Feet total vertical climb. At a slower one mile / hour, considering the bushwhack sections (and a stop at the Killington Peak restaurant) this hike should not take longer than nine hours.

Google Maps Trailhead Directions, Distances (link) from the Hiking Mates CHALLENGE meetup location to the "Logging Road" trailhead on Wheelerville Road near Mendon, VT. USE THE COMMENTS FIELD TO ARRANGE CARPOOLS FROM YOUR AREA.


ESSENTIALS TO BRING: Flash light AND head lamp, food / snacks / at least three bottles of water, first aid items. Wear multiple synthetic layers to adjust for colder fall temperatures.


A view of Mendon Peak, from the summit of Killington Peak.



DETAILS / UPDATE (08/12/2010 11:45 a.m.):
This is a cross-posted trip with Hiking Mates CHALLENGE, the Hike/Snow Shoe Vermont! group, the New England Hiking Meetup and the 4 Seasons Hiking Group. This is the second time we've tried to complete this trip, having to reschedule owing to bad weather. Hope we can finally complete this trip!

This route begins at a logging road at the same parking area along the Wheelerville Road where the Bucklin Trail begins (our return route). You proceed up the rocky, often muddy trail, then approach the Mendon Peak ascent where you take the 3rd and 4th crossings of the narrowing Eddy Brook. There are two bushwhack routes that have been described, the "2nd cairn and "3rd cairn" approaches; maps and links of those trip reports are below. Once we reach the east bump and then the true summit of Mendon Peak, we'll return across the herd path and find our way across the ridgeline to the Long Trail; then turn left to the Copper Lodge and the final ascent to Killington Peak where we can stop at the restaurant and refuel if needed. We'll return down the Bucklin Trail to the cars.

Killington, 2nd highest mountain in Vermont, is at 4,235 feet ASL one of only five mountains in the Green Mountain State rising higher than 4,000 feet ASL. Mendon Peak, at 3,840 feet ASL, is one of the "New England Hundred Highest."

RESEARCH ESSENTIALS:

Killington Peak:
LINK: Peakbagger
LINK: SummitPost
LINK: MountainZone (Mt. Grant)
LINK: Peakbagging the 4000 Footer Mountains of New England


Mendon Peak:
LINK: Peakbagger (Mt. Wilson)
LINK: SummitPost
LINK: MountainZone


The gated start of the "Logging Road" trail to Mendon Peak.



CLICK HERE FOR A TRIP REPORT OF THE "SECOND CAIRN" ROUTE TO MENDON PEAK (SHOWN BELOW).



CLICK HERE FOR A TRIP REPORT OF THE "THIRD CAIRN" ROUTE TO MENDON PEAK (shown below -- thanks to Bob and Geri and "Papa Bear").


CLICK HERE FOR ANOTHER TRIP REPORT OF THE "THIRD CAIRN" ROUTE TO MENDON PEAK (SHOWN BELOW).




See you there! Julie.


WEATHER AND OTHER SUDDEN EVENTS CAN CAUSE SUDDEN CHANGES TO OR CANCELLATION OF THIS EVENT. YOU MUST CHECK BACK TO THE MEETUP.COM SITE OFTEN FOR UPDATES TO ANY HIKING MATES CHALLENGE EVENT.

NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any challenge hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going and how to get back.
item.how_to_find_us: Look for the Green Honda Element ...
item.name: GREEN MOUNTAIN SERIES: Fall on Killington + Mendon Peaks
